reason: As a community, we simply aren't ready for this level of standardization.
description:
As reported repeatedly on the mailing list, in community surveys, and informal communications, the commenting and docstring practices in yt are not standardized.  In particular, @chummels, @ngoldbaum and @brittonsmith have repeatedly mentioned this as a deficiency in recent pull request reviews.

This pull request applies a degree of standardization to both comments and doc strings, reducing disparities in coverage between sections of the code.
title: [ENHANCEMENT] Standardize commenting and docstring practices.

content.raw: This should go back to using multiple lines as this is one really long line.
content.html: This should go back to using multiple lines as this is one really long line.

content.raw: The extra space can be removed.
Multiple lines here would be good.
Something went wrong, you should checkout http://hub.yt:8080/job/yt_testsuite/192/

@MatthewTurk, I like this.  I was skeptical at first, but I think embracing the philosophy that well-written code is self-documenting will hold us to a higher standard moving forward.  Other than my few stylistic comments below, I think this is ready, but we should still wait for three approvals.

It might also be useful to others if you could provide a build of the docs.  I'd like to see how this affects the organizational structure.
content.html:
Matthew Turk, I like this. I was skeptical at first, but I think embracing the philosophy that well-written code is self-documenting will hold us to a higher standard moving forward. Other than my few stylistic comments below, I think this is ready, but we should still wait for three approvals.

It might also be useful to others if you could provide a build of the docs. I'd like to see how this affects the organizational structure.

content.raw:
I'm a bit confused by this PR.  As far as I can tell, huge sections of comments and docstrings are just being removed from the code.  Sometimes the comments are replaced by equivalent whitespace, sometimes not.  Oftentimes the docstrings look OK and compatible with what I thought were the standards for docstrings, but they are removed in their entirety.  If the goal is to get standardization in format of docstrings and comments, I think it may be better to replace/upgrade individual instances of docstrings and comments, rather than just removing things in bulk.  Even unstandardized comments (which still provide information to the reader) are better than no comments. 

Perhaps I'm misunderstanding this PR.  Is this a WIP where we're going to go through and replace the removed comments/docstrings before it is accepted?
